constraints.title: Constraints are design tools.
constraints.paragraphs:
Unlimited options paralyze. We start every project by defining what we won't build. What features won't exist. What use cases won't be supported. What browsers won't be accommodated.

This isn't limitation—it's focus. A system designed for everyone serves no one well.

Constraints force decisions. Decisions create character. Character builds identity.

bilingual.title: Structure that respects direction.
bilingual.paragraphs:
Most sites treat RTL as an afterthought—flipping layouts and hoping it works. We design systems where direction is a first-class citizen.

Because this isn't about translation. It's about cultural adaptation. About understanding that right-aligned navigation isn't just mirrored—it's reconsidered.

Every component. Every layout. Every interaction. Built to work in both directions without compromise.

caseStudy.title: Art Lighting Store
caseStudy.subtitle: High-resolution product imagery at scale. Real-time inventory. Zero-compromise load times.

problem.title: The Problem
problem.description:
The client sold premium lighting fixtures—products where detail matters. Existing platforms compressed images to the point of uselessness. Customers couldn't see finishes, textures, or scale.

Simultaneously, inventory was managed across three systems: physical warehouse, Shopify, and a custom ERP. Updates took hours. Overselling was frequent.

They needed a system that felt expensive, loaded instantly, and stayed in sync.

decision1.title: Image Optimization Without Quality Loss
decision1.description: Standard e-commerce platforms serve one image size to all devices. We built a dynamic image pipeline that generates optimal sizes on-demand and caches aggressively.

decision2.title: Real-Time Inventory Sync
decision2.description: We built a webhook-based inventory system that updates across all platforms within 30 seconds. Overselling became impossible.

decision3.title: Performance Under Load
decision3.description: During peak shopping periods, the site needed to handle 10x normal traffic without degradation. We used edge caching, static generation, and database read replicas.

architecture.title: System Architecture
architecture.description: The system is built as a modular monolith: single deployment, clear boundaries. Each domain (products, orders, inventory) is isolated but shares infrastructure.
architecture.structure:
apps/
├── web/           # Customer-facing store
├── admin/         # Inventory management
└── api/           # Shared API layer

packages/
├── database/      # Prisma schema + migrations
├── images/        # Image optimization pipeline
├── inventory/     # Real-time sync logic
└── payments/      # Stripe integration

infra/
├── cdn/           # Cloudflare edge config
├── database/      # PostgreSQL + read replicas
└── storage/       # R2 for images

results.title: Results
results.description:
The system launched on schedule. Within the first month:

Conversion rate increased 34% (better product imagery made the difference). Page load times dropped from 6.2s to 1.2s. Customer complaints about "site feels slow" disappeared.

Most importantly: the client's team can now manage inventory without technical intervention. The system runs itself.

why-not-wordpress.title: Why we don't use WordPress
why-not-wordpress.excerpt: WordPress powers 43% of the web. We're not part of that 43%. Here's why technical debt compounds faster in WordPress than any other platform.
why-not-wordpress.content:
WordPress powers 43% of the web. It's the default answer for "we need a website." But for technical projects—systems that need to scale, perform, and evolve—WordPress is a liability.

## The Plugin Problem

WordPress's strength is its ecosystem. Need a contact form? There's a plugin. Need SEO? There's a plugin. Need e-commerce? There's a plugin.

This becomes the problem.

Each plugin is a black box. You don't know what it does to your database. You don't know what JavaScript it injects. You don't know what security vulnerabilities it introduces.

When you have 20+ plugins (the average WordPress site), you don't have a system—you have a Jenga tower. Remove one piece, and the whole thing collapses.

## Performance by Default

WordPress generates pages on every request. Even with caching plugins, you're fighting the architecture. Modern frameworks like Next.js generate static pages at build time. The difference isn't marginal—it's orders of magnitude.

A WordPress site with WooCommerce loading in under 2 seconds is impressive. A Next.js site loading in under 2 seconds is concerning.

## The Update Trap

WordPress updates break things. Not occasionally—regularly. Core updates break themes. Theme updates break plugins. Plugin updates break other plugins.

This creates a perverse incentive: don't update. But not updating means accumulating security vulnerabilities.

You're forced to choose between stability and security. Modern frameworks don't have this problem because dependencies are explicit and version-locked.

## When WordPress Makes Sense

WordPress isn't inherently bad. For content-heavy sites managed by non-technical teams, it's often the right choice. Blogs, magazines, small business sites—WordPress excels here.

But for applications? For systems that need to perform under load? For platforms that will evolve over years?

WordPress is the wrong foundation.

technical-debt.title: The cost of technical debt
technical-debt.excerpt: Every shortcut you take today is a loan against tomorrow's velocity. Most teams don't realize they're bankrupt until it's too late.
technical-debt.content:
Technical debt is a loan. Every shortcut you take today must be repaid—with interest.

Most teams understand this conceptually. Few understand it viscerally until they're drowning.

## The Compounding Problem

Financial debt compounds monthly. Technical debt compounds with every new feature.

Skip writing tests? Now every change is risky. Skip documentation? Now every new developer is slow. Skip refactoring? Now every feature takes longer than the last.

The interest rate on technical debt is variable—and it accelerates. A small shortcut taken in month one might cost 10x by month twelve.

## The Types of Debt

### Deliberate Debt

Sometimes shortcuts are strategic. Ship fast, learn, iterate. This is acceptable if:
1. You document what was skipped
2. You plan time to repay it
3. You actually repay it

Most teams fail at step 3.

### Accidental Debt

This is debt from ignorance. The junior developer who doesn't know best practices. The rushed senior who ships without thinking.

Accidental debt is expensive because no one knows it exists until it breaks.

### Bit Rot

Code doesn't stay good. Dependencies update. Browsers change. Security vulnerabilities emerge. Code that was fine last year is a liability today.

Bit rot isn't optional—it's inevitable. The only question is whether you're maintaining or accumulating.

## The Bankruptcy Moment

There's a point where technical debt becomes terminal. Where the cost of change exceeds the value of the system.

You know you're there when:
- Simple changes take weeks
- Deploys are terrifying
- Developers leave rather than deal with the codebase
- The only solution is "rewrite from scratch"

Most rewrites fail. Not because the code is hard—because the organization hasn't changed the behaviors that created the debt.

## How to Avoid Bankruptcy

### Budget for Maintenance

Plan 20-30% of engineering time for debt repayment. Not features. Not bugs. Debt.

Refactoring. Testing. Documentation. Dependency updates. Security patches.

If you're not spending time here, you're accumulating debt.

### Make Debt Visible

Create a debt register. List every known shortcut, hack, or "we'll fix it later" decision.

Review it quarterly. Prioritize. Pay down the highest-interest items first.

### Slow Down to Go Fast

The fastest way to build a system is to build it carefully the first time.

Tests slow down initial development but speed up long-term velocity. Documentation feels wasteful until someone new joins. Refactoring feels indulgent until you need to change something.

The teams that ship fast in year one are often the teams that can't ship at all by year three.

evaluating-developers.title: How to evaluate development partners
evaluating-developers.excerpt: Agencies promise the world. Freelancers promise speed. In-house promises control. All three are wrong. Here's what actually matters.
evaluating-developers.content:
Most businesses evaluate development partners wrong. They optimize for cost, speed, or impressive portfolios. Then they're surprised when the project fails.

Here's what actually predicts success.

## Not Portfolio—Process

A beautiful portfolio proves they can build one thing well. It doesn't prove they can build your thing well.

Instead, ask about process:
- How do you handle changing requirements?
- What happens when you disagree with a decision?
- How do you prioritize when everything is urgent?
- What's your approach to technical debt?

Their answers reveal how they think, not just what they've built.

## Not Speed—Velocity

Speed is how fast they start. Velocity is how fast they maintain pace.

Many developers sprint for the first month and crawl by month three. Why? Because they accumulated debt without realizing it.

Ask:
- How do you maintain velocity over time?
- What's your approach to refactoring?
- How do you handle dependency updates?

Partners who talk about sustainability over speed will deliver more in the long run.

## Not Promises—Boundaries

Good developers know their limits. They'll say "I don't know" or "That's not my expertise."

Bad developers promise everything. They'll figure it out along the way (at your expense).

If they haven't said "no" or "I'm not sure" in the sales conversation, they're selling, not consulting.

## Not Technology—Judgment

The tech stack matters less than the reasoning behind it.

A developer who says "We use React because it's popular" is following trends.

A developer who says "We use React because your team already knows it, and onboarding new developers will be faster" is making strategic decisions.

Ask why they choose specific technologies. The quality of their reasoning matters more than the technologies themselves.

## The Red Flags

### They Lead with Tools

If the first thing they talk about is their tech stack, they're technologists, not problem solvers.

Good developers start with questions, not solutions.

### They Don't Ask About Maintenance

If they don't ask who will maintain the system after launch, they're not thinking long-term.

### They Quote Without Discovery

No one can accurately estimate a project without understanding it. Fixed quotes before discovery phase = guaranteed scope creep or cut corners.

### They Don't Talk About Trade-offs

Every technical decision is a trade-off. Speed vs. maintainability. Flexibility vs. simplicity. Cost vs. performance.

If they're not discussing trade-offs, they're not thinking critically.

## The Green Flags

### They Ask About Your Team

They want to know who will work with the system, who will maintain it, and what your team's technical capabilities are.

### They Push Back

They question requirements. They challenge assumptions. They suggest alternatives.

This isn't rudeness—it's rigor.

### They Talk About Constraints

They ask about budget, timeline, and must-haves. They help you prioritize. They tell you what you can't have.

### They Explain Simply

Complex topics explained clearly = deep understanding. Complex topics explained complexly = shallow understanding or gatekeeping.

## The Question to Ask

"Tell me about a project that went wrong and how you handled it."

Their answer tells you:
- Whether they're honest (everyone has failures)
- How they handle adversity
- Whether they learn from mistakes
- How they communicate bad news

If they say they've never had a failed project, they're lying or inexperienced. Either way, walk away.

multilingual-architecture.title: Multi-language web architecture
multilingual-architecture.excerpt: Most 'bilingual' websites are English sites with Arabic text. Real multi-language support means rethinking structure from the ground up.
multilingual-architecture.content:
Most websites that claim "multi-language support" have English structure with translated text. They flip the layout for RTL languages and call it done.

This is not multi-language architecture. It's translation theater.

Real multi-language support means reconsidering everything—from database schema to component design to navigation patterns.

## The Text Direction Problem

RTL (Right-to-Left) languages like Arabic and Hebrew don't just read backwards. They think differently.

Navigation structure, visual hierarchy, even whitespace usage differs between LTR and RTL contexts.

Most sites apply `dir="rtl"` and mirror everything with CSS. This breaks:
- Icons (arrows point the wrong way)
- Layouts (elements stack incorrectly)
- Interactions (swipe gestures feel backwards)

### The Solution

Direction must be a first-class citizen in your component system.

```typescript
const Button = ({{ children, icon }}) => {{
  const {{ direction }} = useLocale()
  const Icon = direction === 'rtl' ? FlippedIcon : icon
  return <button>{{children}} <Icon /></button>
}}
```

Every component considers direction. Not as an afterthought—as a core parameter.

## The Content Length Problem

Arabic text is typically 20-30% longer than equivalent English. German can be 40% longer.

Layouts designed for English break when content expands.

### Common Failures

- Fixed-width navigation items that overflow
- Buttons that wrap to multiple lines
- Truncated headlines that lose meaning
- Layouts that shift based on content length

### The Solution

Design for maximum expected length, not average length.

Use flexible layouts. Avoid fixed widths. Test with the longest language first.

## The URL Structure Problem

How do you structure URLs for multiple languages?

### Option 1: Subdomain
`ar.example.com` vs `example.com`

Pros: Clear separation, easier CDN configuration
Cons: SEO complexity, shared authentication challenges

### Option 2: Path-based
`example.com/ar/about` vs `example.com/about`

Pros: Single domain, easier authentication
Cons: More complex routing

### Option 3: Query Parameter
`example.com/about?lang=ar`

Pros: Simple implementation
Cons: Poor SEO, not shareable, user-hostile

### Our Choice

Path-based. It's the most user-friendly and SEO-friendly approach.

## The Database Problem

How do you store multi-language content?

### Approach 1: Separate Tables
```sql
CREATE TABLE products_en (id, name, description)
CREATE TABLE products_ar (id, name, description)
```

Pros: Simple queries
Cons: Data duplication, schema maintenance nightmare

### Approach 2: JSON Columns
```sql
CREATE TABLE products (
  id INT,
  name JSONB, -- {{ "en": "Product", "ar": "منتج" }}
  description JSONB
)
```

Pros: Single source of truth
Cons: Complex queries, type safety issues

### Approach 3: Translation Tables
```sql
CREATE TABLE products (id, sku)
CREATE TABLE product_translations (
  product_id,
  locale,
  name,
  description
)
```

Pros: Flexible, maintainable, type-safe
Cons: More complex queries

### Our Choice

Translation tables. They scale better and maintain referential integrity.

## The Component Problem

Components must handle:
- Direction-aware layouts
- Text length variations
- Locale-specific formatting (dates, numbers, currency)
- Cultural adaptations (colors, imagery)

### Example: Date Picker

In English: MM/DD/YYYY
In Arabic: DD/MM/YYYY
In Swedish: YYYY-MM-DD

Your date picker must adapt format, first day of week, and month names.

```typescript
import {{ format }} from 'date-fns'
import {{ ar, enUS }} from 'date-fns/locale'

const formatDate = (date, locale) => {{
  const localeMap = {{ ar, en: enUS }}
  return format(date, 'P', {{ locale: localeMap[locale] }})
}}
```

## The Testing Problem

Multi-language sites require multi-language testing.

- Visual regression testing in both directions
- Content length testing at extremes
- Translation accuracy (not just presence)
- Cultural appropriateness

## The Performance Problem

Serving multiple languages can degrade performance if not handled correctly.

### Bundle Size

Loading all translations upfront = massive bundle.

### Solution

Code-split by language. Load only the active locale.

```typescript
import(`@/locales/${{locale}}.json`).then(setTranslations)
```

### Font Loading

Arabic typography requires different fonts than Latin. Loading both = wasted bandwidth.

### Solution

Conditionally load fonts based on active locale.

```css
@font-face {{
  font-family: 'Primary';
  src: url('/fonts/latin.woff2');
  unicode-range: U+0000-00FF;
}}

@font-face {{
  font-family: 'Primary';
  src: url('/fonts/arabic.woff2');
  unicode-range: U+0600-06FF;
}}
```

## The Reality

True multi-language support requires:
- Database restructuring
- Component redesign
- Layout adaptation
- Performance optimization
- Cultural consultation

It's not a feature. It's an architectural decision.

Most teams underestimate the work by 3-5x.

If you're adding multi-language support to an existing codebase, expect to touch every component, every layout, and every data model.

If you're starting fresh, make it a first-class concern from day one. Build the infrastructure before you need it.

Because retrofitting multi-language support is painful. Designing it in from the start is just... design.
